channel.title: Nature Materials
channel.description: Nature Materials is a multidisciplinary journal aimed at bringing together cutting-edge research across the entire spectrum of materials science and technology. Nature Materials covers all applied and fundamental aspects of the synthesis/processing, structure/composition, properties and performance of materials. Nature Materials provides a forum for the development of a common identity among materials scientists while encouraging researchers to cross established subdisciplinary lines. To achieve this, Nature Materials takes an interdisciplinary, integrated and balanced approach to all areas of materials research while fostering the exchange of ideas between scientists involved in different communities.

item.title: Tweezer arrays advance quantum computing
item.content:encoded:
Nature Materials, Published online: 21 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41563-025-02432-2

Tweezer arrays advance quantum computing
item.dc:title: Tweezer arrays advance quantum computing
item.dc:creator: Amos Martinez

item.title: Moiré enhanced flat band in rhombohedral graphene
item.content:encoded:
Nature Materials, Published online: 21 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41563-025-02416-2

Through direct visualization of how the moiré potential enhances and modulates the topological flat band in rhombohedral graphene superlattice, this work provides key insights into the microscopic mechanism of the fractional quantum anomalous Hall effect
item.dc:title: Moiré enhanced flat band in rhombohedral graphene

item.title: A crystal that breathes
item.content:encoded:
Nature Materials, Published online: 19 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41563-025-02424-2

An organic crystal containing open channels and discrete voids responds to CO2 gas pressure by reversibly elongating along a single crystal axis. Although the voids initially appear too small to host CO2, structural flexibility permits gradual gas penetration and void expansion, triggering a cascading deformation that amplifies macroscopically.
item.dc:title: A crystal that breathes

item.title: Sealing stretchable electronics through a viscoplastic surface effect
item.content:encoded:
Nature Materials, Published online: 18 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41563-025-02417-1

By harnessing the viscoplastic surface effect, researchers have created a stretchable hermetic seal that enables the reliable encapsulation of stretchable electronics.
item.dc:title: Sealing stretchable electronics through a viscoplastic surface effect
item.dc:creator: Haeseung Lee
Jiheong Kang

item.title: Brownian spin-locking effect
item.content:encoded:
Nature Materials, Published online: 18 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41563-025-02413-5

The authors report a large-scale spin-locking effect of light within a Brownian medium arising from the intrinsic spin–orbit interactions of scattering from multiple individual nanoparticles in a complex disordered system.
item.dc:title: Brownian spin-locking effect
item.dc:creator: Xiao Zhang
Peiyang Chen
Mei Li
Yuzhi Shi
Erez Hasman
Bo Wang
Xianfeng Chen

item.title: Scalable ruthenium core–shell hydrogen catalyst for efficient and robust proton-exchange membrane electrolyser
item.content:encoded:
Nature Materials, Published online: 14 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41563-025-02405-5

Green hydrogen production often needs Pt-based electrolysers; however, their high cost and lack of scalability hinder uptake. Here a core–shell Ru-based electrolyser is demonstrated for acidic hydrogen evolution and demonstrates a low overpotential and Pt-like stability, as well as scalability to a 200 cm2 device.
item.dc:title: Scalable ruthenium core–shell hydrogen catalyst for efficient and robust proton-exchange membrane electrolyser
item.dc:creator: Jinze Li
Haiyang Cheng
